Key Arguments: The legislation threatens freedom of speech and expression, which are essential in a democratic society.
No single organization, including ACMA, should have the authority to define truth, as truths can change over time.
The legislation should not exempt the government, as this would be suspicious and unfair.
Non-violent discussions should be encouraged to allow for multiple interpretations and opinions.
The ability for ACMA to gather information about social media users is an overreach and threatens internet anonymity.
Main Themes: Privacy and anonymity on the internet
Notable Quotes: I believe that freedom of speech and freedom of expression is paramount in any democratic society.
No single organisation (in this case, ACMA) should be able to define what is 'truth' and what it is not.
Removal or restriction of freedom of speech and freedom of expression lead to reduction in freedom of thought, of ideation.
One of the fundamental tenets of the internet, from its inception, through to its current-day format, is for people to remain anonymous when they so desire.
